title: March 15 incident
text:
The was a crackdown on <a href="socialism">socialists</a> and <a href="Japanese%20Communist%20Party">communists</a> by the Japanese government in 1928. Among those who were arrested in the incident was <a href="Marxist%20economist">Marxist economist</a> <a href="Kawakami%20Hajime">Kawakami Hajime</a>.
Background.
Although the <a href="Japan%20Communist%20Party">Japan Communist Party</a> had been outlawed and forced underground immediately after its foundation in 1922, it continued to gather strength and membership in the volatile social and economic climate of <a href="Taish%C5%8D%20period">Japan in the 1920s</a>. During the <a href="1928%20Japanese%20general%20election">February 1928 General Election</a>, which was the first held in Japan following the passage of universal male <a href="suffrage">suffrage</a>, the Japan Communist Party was very visible in its support of the legal socialist and labor-oriented political parties. Alarmed by gains these parties made in the <a href="Diet%20of%20Japan">Diet of Japan</a>, the conservative government of <a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20Japan">Prime Minister</a> <a href="Giichi%20Tanaka">Giichi Tanaka</a> (which had retained its majority by only one seat) evoked the provisions of the 1925 <a href="Peace%20Preservation%20Law">Peace Preservation Law</a>s and ordered the <a href="mass%20arrest">mass arrest</a> of known communists and suspected communist sympathizers. The arrests occurred throughout Japan, and a total of 1652 people were apprehended.
Consequences.
About 500 of those arrested were eventually prosecuted, in a series of open trials held by the <a href="Tokyo%20District%20Court">Tokyo District Court</a> starting from 15 June 1932, with sentencing on 2 July 1932. These public trials were carefully staged to publicize the inner workings of the secretive <a href="Japan%20Communist%20Party">Japan Communist Party</a>, and with its connections with the <a href="labor%20movement">labor movement</a> and other left-wing political parties revealed, the government was able to order the dissolution of the "<a href="R%C5%8Dd%C5%8D%20N%C5%8Dmint%C5%8D">Rōdō Nōmintō</a>" (Labor-Farmer Party), the "<a href="Zen%20Nihon%20Musan%20Seinen%20D%C5%8Dmei">Zen Nihon Musan Seinen Dōmei</a>" (All-Japan Proletarian Youth League) and the "<a href="Nihon%20R%C5%8Dd%C5%8D%20Kumiai%20Hy%C5%8Dgikai">Nihon Rōdō Kumiai Hyōgikai</a>" (Council of Japanese Labor Unions). The defendants in the trials were all found guilty and sentenced to stiff jail terms; however, those who recanted their communist ideology were then pardoned or given much reduced terms. This was the beginning of the "<a href="tenk%C5%8D">tenkō</a>" policy designed to reintegrate former leftists into mainstream society. Perhaps more importantly, as a consequence of these trials, Prime Minister Tanaka was able to pass legislation which added the provision for the <a href="death%20penalty">death penalty</a> to the already draconian Peace Preservation Laws.
Writer <a href="Kobayashi%20Takiji">Kobayashi Takiji</a> later wrote "March 15, 1928" based on this incident.
